div1.head: Letter from G. Jameson Carr to Henry Rose Carter, May 22, 1924

div1.p:
I have the honour to submit that I received an order from Dr Scannell
dated Bahia, April 17. to report to you any observations I might have made
regarding the question as to whether Aedes AEgypti would breed in mud puddles.

item.p:
(1) Since January 1. 1924 I have ordered my personel to report to me at once
any larvae they found in mud puddles.

In no case so reported and visited at once personally, have I been able to
verify Aedes Aegypti, all cases have been either, Culex Fatigans or Aedes
(Howardina) Aureostriatus, or collections of water recently emptied from
deposits where there already were larvae or pupae.

This investigation was stimulated after reading West African reports in
November last year.

(2). A tin basin .55 cm in diameter by .14 cm deep was filled with a mixture,
half and half, of clean dry sand, yellow in colour, and top layer black humus
from my garden and packed tightly including the edges, so that no tin was
exposed.

One half of the edge was covered with the sand to leave a choice in colour
the other half being black.

The center was scooped out to form a concavity 40 cm in diameter and 9 cm
deep at the center.

Water was carefully added so as not to disturb the surfaces of the edges
and filled the concavity to a depth of 8 cm. leaving an edge of 75 cm not
covered but which quickly became moist by capillarity, showing a fine film
over the sand and humus. (by magnifying glass, times 14).

div1.p: PRAÇA 1817 N.o 181

DEPARTAMENTO DE SAUDE PUBLICA
COMMISSÃO DA FEBRE AMARELLA
PARAHYBA DO NORTE--BRASIL
CAIXA POSTAL, N.o 41

The water was allowed to stand under protective netting for twenty four hours
and then tested by Phenol red giving a Ph. of 7, 6. and after acidification
by a drop of HNO3, in 20 cc, plus AgNO3 3 drops, gave slight turbidity of NACl.
The temperature of the water through-out the experiment varied between 22° and 25°C.
ON May 7. 1924. A male hare and 5 male and 6 female Aedes Aegypti were put,
together with the artificial mud puddle, into my experimental cage, size 1.10 m.
square, means being employed to protect the puddle from the hare.

The females had been bred out two days before under lantern jars, had had no
blood or other feed, but copulation was frequent.

AS soon as the hare had settled down to his quarters, which was half an hour,
the first females were seen to be feeding on his ears (8.30 am).

(Here I might mention that I have found white hares the best for blood feeds
as the mosquitos show up well and the ears being long and heavy they cannot
be waggled so as to dislodge the insect as in the case of rabbit or pig,
but it is well to place a buck and dam together as the buck tends to become
very wild and will tear down netting and other erections seemingly out of
sheer exuberance).

At 10.30 pm two females were seen to be depositing eggs, one on the sand and
the other on the humus, 3 and 5 cm respectively, away from the actual body of
water, there- after eggs were deposited by all the females indescriminately
over both sand and humus edges but no further than 5 cm away from the water
in any case, nor nearer than 1 cm, until the 18th when the last female died.
(All males had died by the 14th).

On the 11th, 10 am, the first larvae was seen to be wriggling down to the water
in the film and it took exactly 3 hours and 10 minutes to reach the main body
a distance of 4 and a half cms.

This phenomenon was witnessed and is still progressing to the date of writing
the puddle being now literally alive with larvae in all periods, and pupae.
PRAÇA 1817 N.o 181

DEPARTAMENTO DE SAUDE PUBLICA
COMMISSÃO DA FEBRE AMARELLA
PARAHYBA DO NORTE--BRASIL
CAIXA POSTAL, N.o 41
On the 19th at 2 pm the first pupa was seen.
On the 21st the same had become an adult male (9.30 pm.)
On the 22nd, to-day, 10 more pupae have become adults, 7 males and 3 females.

I realize that this experiment can only demonstrate that Aedes Aegypti will
lay, if forced, on the edge of mud puddles and thereafter the eggs will develope
and the larvae migrate through the surface film to the main body of water
to complete the full cycle, protected against rain, sun, natural enemies
and disturbances of animals and man, especially against ants ( in the egg
stage), which I have found particularly fond of them.

In another experiment I found that Aedes Aegypti preferred plain wooden barrels
against 14 other recepticles offered, including muddy water in an earthenware
jar.

I shall continue to watch for the natural phenomenon and report at once if found
while deeming it a favour if I can carry out any particular experiment for you.
Neither my training nor the means at my disposal are such as to enable me to
do other than very simple observations but each day brings the joy of something
new seen and registered.
I have the honour to be
Sir

your obedient servant G. Jameson Carr. Dr H.R. Carter.
